profile_positions.description:
Social Enterprise NL advocates for an impact economy in the Netherlands and facilitates the development of social enterprise ecosystems. 

I currently lead their international project entitled 'Leveraging the Influencing Capacity of Social Enterprises', that aims to assist SEs in pushing the business community towards realizing the SDGs. By applying a systems lens, SEs can identify where they can exercise greater influence on the business community, determine an actionable influencing strategy, and work effectively towards systems change. More information can be found in attached media.

This project will be finalized in 2023 in collaboration with our partners: Porticus, Amsterdam Impact, Catalyst 2030, Social Change Innovators, Yunus Social Business, Ashoka, IKEA Social Entrepreneurship, and SEWF.

profile_positions.description:
MOSS is a consultancy and financier that aims to maximize the impact of social entrepreneurs in developing and emerging markets by providing workshops and consulting services built around our systems change expertise.

Our capacity-building services draw from complexity theory and paradox theory and are designed to help change agents in their efforts by making systems thinking tools and approaches accessible and practicable.  

We work with various impact ecosystem stakeholders ranging from NGOs, universities, and government entities to multinational corporations, entrepreneurs, and impact investors. Our focus, however, is on facilitating local social innovators – specifically social entrepreneurs – in adopting systems thinking mindsets and approaches.

This is borne out of our conviction that local communities understand best the complexities of local socio-ecological problems and are therefore better positioned to catalyze systems change.

In the Executive Education department of RSM, my role as an LDM entailed two distinct yet correlated objectives: to develop quality business programs for professional mid-to-senior level managers, and, to improve departmental systems of knowledge collection, organization, analysis, and dissemination. 

► Program Development

In this role I focused predominantly on meeting current market needs by co-creating programs with internal and external stakeholders. This included the design, development, and delivery of both open and custom programs; the former are short open-enrollment courses typically of 3-5 days duration while the latter are customized courses of varying duration for specific multinationals. My emphasis was on expanding RSM’s Open Program portfolio with market-relevant offerings.

► Systems Design

In this role I initiated internal projects aimed at improving a plethora of departmental structures and processes that support program development. While originating from personal needs in Open Program development, these efforts have since scaled towards systemic innovations that influence multiple functions in the department. As such, projects have been adopted and adapted by cross-function teams as a means to improving department-wide effectiveness. As a budding change manager in an extremely complex corporate and academic environment, I realized many of these projects to various levels of success.

profile_positions.description:
The Op Stop was a not-for-profit social enterprise that I founded together with some friends during my final semester at RMIT in Melbourne. It consisted of a mobile opportunity shop, The Op Stop van, which collected and sold fashionable second-hand clothing at high school and university campuses as well as inner- Melbourne markets. The objective of the venture was to raise both funds and awareness for tackling social issues amongst Melbourne youths. We did so in collaboration with local partners such as with the Youth Support & Advocacy Service (YSAS) on drugs and alcohol abuse.

As the founder, owner, and manager of the company, I was responsible for venture financing, all legal registrations and permits, vehicle logistics, bookkeeping, daily operations management including volunteer scheduling, inventory management, marketing activities, and executing our exit strategy. I managed a small team of volunteers in these areas and oversaw all business activities from entry to exit.

volunteer_experiences.description:
Kromkommer is a social enterprise aimed at reducing food wastage in the Netherlands; specifically, fruit and vegetable produce waste within national production and distribution chains. It was founded by two charismatic classmates of mine in January 2013 and has since scaled its product offering and distribution to leading Dutch supermarkets.

My contribution to the endeavor has been carried out on two fronts. On the one hand, I have been a regular ‘traditional’ volunteer, helping out whenever possible at events such as fundraising events or during marketing campaigns. On the other hand I have provided business strategy advice regarding upscaling and business development, lending an ear when requested on growth concerns and reviewing business expansion plans.

Goodget is a startup company based in the Netherlands but operating in Ghana. It is essentially a logistics business for innovative products that address the needs of the bottom of the pyramid. Through the use of a microfranchise formula, the organization is creating a much-needed market platform in Africa for producers and consumers of such proven, practical, cost-effective, and sustainable solutions.

When I volunteered, the business was in its infancy and was solely run by the CEO and one other volunteer. My immediate contribution was to business formation, where I helped write the business plan of the startup for use in fundraising efforts. Later, I was asked to produce a number of reports on the potential of Ghana as an initial launching market: a market research plan, a logistics plan, and a product selection report. I enlisted three student colleagues with complementary skill sets and managed the team towards the successful completion of each report. The company has since launched successfully in Ghana based in no small part on recommendations from these reports.

My involvement with the company after the intensive first 5 months has been in an advisory position to the CEO, where I have made recommendations when requested regarding business strategy, business growth and upscaling, fundraising, and marketing.

The Social Enterprise Consulting arm of the Erasmus University Rotterdam (SECEUR; now SOLVE) is a student-run consultancy whose objective is to facilitate nonprofit organizations as well as social businesses in delivering impact more efficiently and more effectively.

My assignment was a management consulting project for a Netherlands-based international NPO: Edukans. The organization aims for universal access to education and focuses its efforts on developing countries. The immediate issue they were facing was the withdrawal of government funding within the nonprofit sector and the subsequent gap between revenue and project-allocated funds.

Together with three other consultants, we assessed and analyzed the fundraising mechanism of Edukans as well as their project-allocation processes. Aiming to fill the funding gap, we restructured their corporate fundraising initiatives as well as the associated internal management support structures. Moreover, project proposals and funding allocation procedures were standardized to remove inefficiencies and further shorten the funding gap. Our report was well received by the client who subsequently implemented its recommendations.

SAN Nepal is an NPO dedicated to alleviating poverty and improving living conditions for disadvantaged people in Nepal’s rural communities. Various initiatives are currently undertaken by the organization including educational services, micro-credit financing, and agricultural enterprise.

My initial involvement constituted an in-depth 4-week consultation process at the time when the young organization was experiencing ‘growing pains’. It was experiencing considerable difficulty in guaranteeing quality standards through its diversification process from micro-credit financing into educational services and agricultural enterprise while also wrestling with financial pressures and stakeholder pressures stemming from operational inefficiencies and initiative-level mismanagement. 

As a change agent, I analyzed and addressed these issues within SAN Nepal, identifying the G.I.A Academy in Rauwahi as the primary vehicle for sustainable change within the organization. My analysis of business and stakeholder management weaknesses and opportunities and subsequent execution and monitoring of various significant changes at the academy ultimately: removed curricular inefficiencies, improved relations with the community, and reduced its operating costs by 12.5%. Within this unfamiliar cultural landscape I was able to generate significant support by making the changes visible and tangible to all stakeholders. This demonstration motivated the CEO to embark on similar processes in other areas of SAN Nepal.

Since then, the organization has successfully scaled up its various operations within Nepal and I have maintained an advisory role to the CEO throughout, advising him on business management, innovation processes, and fundraising initiatives when requested.
